figure_1:
Schematic representation
of the long and tedious histopathology
process. The patients need to undergo initial scanning to identify
the tumor. This is followed by a sample section which further undergoes
multiple processing steps taking longer time and needs to be confirmed
by a neuropathologist which increases the chances of error. An error
or partial removal of tumor leads to invasive surgery, again affecting
the health and quality of life of patient. (Created with Biorender.com.)

MRI, Raman image, and
Raman spectra of normal brain tissues (a).
Raman image and Raman spectra of medulloblastoma (b). Lipid (red)
and proteins (blue). The decrease in the intensity of red color in

in tumor tissues which is affirmed by a high intensity blue peak (protein)

figure_6:
Graphical representation
of SRS imaging diagnostic platform for
rapid glioblastoma subtyping. Here, the image stack denotes the tissue
area obtained under an SRS microscope. Each tile of the stack undergoes
multivariate curve analysis to express the major spectral components.
Among those components, the decomposed spectra are used for subtyping
glioblastoma while reconstructed concentration maps are merged to
give histological images.74 Reprinted from
